No, it's not. In 2) we're saying a connection is a 1-form DDD valued in differential operators on sections of EEE, such that for any vector field vvv on MMM we get an operator DvD_vDv​ obeying

Dv(fs)=v(f)s+fDvs D_v (fs) = v(f) s + f D_v sDv​(fs)=v(f)s+fDv​s

Dv(s+t)=Dvs+DvtD_v(s + t) = D_v s + D_v t Dv​(s+t)=Dv​s+Dv​t

There's nothing about an End(E)\mathrm{End}(E)End(E)-valued 1-form here! Nor is any trivialization of EEE required here.

When we trivialize EEE - and not before we do this! - we can define an operation ddd on sections of EEE. Then we can define an End(E)\mathrm{End}(E)End(E)-valued 1-form AAA on MMM by

As=Dvs−ds(v)As = D_v s - ds(v) As=Dv​s−ds(v)

Then we get the formula

D=d+A D = d + AD=d+A

But this splitting of DDD into two parts, the ddd part and the AAA part, is trivialization-dependent. I'd say that DDD is more fundamental, because it's defined independent of a trivialization of EEE.

John Baez (Oct 22 2024 at 21:12):

John Onstead said:

End(V)\mathrm{End}(V)End(V) is of course functorial by two metrics! First, we know that End(V)=V⊗V∗\mathrm{End}(V)=V \otimes V^*End(V)=V⊗V∗, so if the latter is a (contravariant) functor, and obviously tensor products are, then the whole thing is a functor by composition (though I believe when passing to the opposite category you have to turn the tensor product into a "co-tensor product"). In addition, End(V)\mathrm{End}(V)End(V) is just the internal hom: End(V)=Hom(V,V)\mathrm{End}(V)=\mathrm{Hom}(V,V)End(V)=Hom(V,V)!

Both these attempts suffer from the problem that

V∗⊗W≅Hom(V,W) V^\ast \otimes W \cong \mathrm{Hom}(V,W)V∗⊗W≅Hom(V,W)

is contravariant in VVV and covariant in WWW. So while there's perfectly fine functor

Hom:Vectop×Vect→Vect \mathrm{Hom}: \mathsf{Vect}^{\text{op}} \times \mathsf{Vect} \to \mathsf{Vect} Hom:Vectop×Vect→Vect

mapping (V,W)(V,W)(V,W) to Hom(V,W)\mathrm{Hom}(V,W)Hom(V,W), it turns out that there is no functor

End:Vect→Vect\mathrm{End} : \mathsf{Vect} \to \mathsf{Vect}End:Vect→Vect

mapping VVV to Hom(V,V)\mathrm{Hom}(V,V)Hom(V,V). That is, having defined this would-be functor on objects by

V→Hom(V,V)V \to \mathrm{Hom}(V,V)V→Hom(V,V),

there's no way to define it on morphisms to get a functor from Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect to itself.

Of course this requires proof, and I haven't provided a proof, so there's an implicit puzzle here: how do we prove it?

There is, however, a functor

End:core(Vect)→core(Vect)\mathrm{End} : \mathsf{core(Vect)} \to \mathsf{core(Vect)}End:core(Vect)→core(Vect)

sending VVV to Hom(V,V)\mathrm{Hom}(V,V)Hom(V,V). That is, having defined this would-be functor on objects by

V→Hom(V,V)V \to \mathrm{Hom}(V,V)V→Hom(V,V),

we can define it isomorphisms in Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect and get a functor from core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect) to itself.

There's another implicit puzzle here: how do we define End\mathrm{End}End on isomorphisms? I'll just say it doesn't depend on any special features of Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect; it works for any symmetric monoidal closed category... and I'm sticking in 'symmetric' just to be super-careful; I don't think it's needed.

John Baez (Oct 22 2024 at 21:19):

The point of all this baloney, lest we lose sight of it, is that parallel transport along a path always gives an isomorphism from one fiber to another. So, we expect any construction we can do to fibers, which is functorial with respect to isomorphisms, can serve as a way to build a new bundle from an old one, and also turn a connection on the old one into a connection on the new one.

John Baez (Oct 22 2024 at 21:20):

(In reality we need not just functoriality but also 'smoothness', since a connection can be seen as a smooth functor from the path groupoid to the groupoid with fibers as objects and suitable smooth maps between fibers as morphisms.)

John Onstead (Oct 22 2024 at 21:25):

John Baez said:

The point of all this baloney, lest we lose sight of it, is that parallel transport along a path always gives an isomorphism from one fiber to another. So, we expect any construction we can do to fibers, which is functorial with respect to isomorphisms, can serve as a way to build a new bundle from an old one, and also turn a connection on the old one into a connection on the new one.

That's a good summary!

John Onstead (Oct 22 2024 at 21:26):

John Baez said:

So while there's perfectly fine functor

Hom:Vectop×Vect→Vect \mathrm{Hom}: \mathsf{Vect}^{\text{op}} \times \mathsf{Vect} \to \mathsf{Vect} Hom:Vectop×Vect→Vect

mapping (V,W)(V,W)(V,W) to Hom(V,W)\mathrm{Hom}(V,W)Hom(V,W)

Ah, that must have been what I was thinking of, my bad!

John Onstead (Oct 22 2024 at 21:26):

John Baez said:

It's not so well-known, so I can easily understand why you didn't read my mind the first time! I think you can find some version of it here:

  • Urs Schreiber and Konrad Waldorf, Parallel transport and functors.

Thanks, I'll check this out!

John Baez said:

But this splitting of DDD into two parts, the ddd part and the AAA part, is trivialization-dependent. I'd say that DDD is more fundamental, because it's defined independent of a trivialization of EEE.

I think I understand! I'm just confused about one other thing- the above statement "When we trivialize EEE- and not before we do this! - we can define an operation ddd on sections of EEE". But the operation ddd is just the exterior derivative- it doesn't need a trivialization, or really for that matter a bundle at all to work. Maybe you meant to say "When we trivialize EEE- and not before we do this! - we can define an operation AAA on sections of EEE" instead?

John Baez (Oct 22 2024 at 22:44):

You can define ddd of a smooth function on a manifold MMM without any extra structure. But now we are talking about defining ddd on a section of a vector bundle E→ME \to ME→M. To do this, we choose a trivialization of EEE, i.e. an isomorphism between E→ME \to ME→M and M×Rn→MM \times \mathbb{R}^n \to MM×Rn→M. After doing this, and only after doing this, we can identify a section of EEE with an n-tuple of smooth functions fi:M→Rf_i : M \to \mathbb{R}fi​:M→R. This lets us define ddd of a section of EEE by

d(f1,…,fn)=(df1,…,dfn) d(f_1, \dots, f_n) = (df_1, \dots, df_n)d(f1​,…,fn​)=(df1​,…,dfn​)

But if we changed the trivalization, we'd get a different ddd operator for sections of EEE!

John Baez (Oct 22 2024 at 22:49):

So: given a vector field vvv, the covariant derivative DvsD_v sDv​s of a section sss of EEE can be defined using only connection on EEE.

But when we write it this way:

Dvs=(ds)(v)+A(v)s D_v s = (d s)(v) + A(v) s Dv​s=(ds)(v)+A(v)s

we need to have trivialized EEE to know what the EEE-valued 1-form dsd sds actually is! And this, in turn, determines what the End(E)\mathrm{End}(E)End(E)-valued 1-form AAA is.

If we change the trivialization, ddd and A AA change, but DDD itself does not.

John Baez (Oct 22 2024 at 22:55):

By the way, if you don't mind covariant exterior derivatives we can write the above equation as

Ds=ds+A∧s D s = d s + A \wedge sDs=ds+A∧s

or even as

D=d+A∧− D = d + A \wedge -D=d+A∧−

or maybe more tersely as

D=d+A D = d + A D=d+A

but these variants don't change the essential point: the way of splitting the left side into two parts depends on a choice of trivialization.

John Baez (Oct 22 2024 at 23:10):

By the way, in my book on pages 226-227, I write the ddd operator for sections of a trivialized vector bundle EEE as D0D^0D0, and I call it the standard flat connection associated to the trivialization. That is probably safer than overloading the meaning of ddd. But lots of people write it as ddd.

John Onstead (Oct 23 2024 at 11:17):

That's very interesting! It seems that ddd acts as a sort of partial derivative, and so requires local coordinates to make sense, which can only be specified after the trivialization. At least I hope I'm understanding that right!

I wanted to return to the issue that started this discussion in the first place, which was defining how to extend a connection on EEE to one on E∗E^*E∗ and End(E)\mathrm{End}(E)End(E):
John Baez said:

Next, any endofunctor F:core(Vect)→core(Vect)F : \mathsf{core(Vect)} \to \mathsf{core(Vect)} F:core(Vect)→core(Vect) acts on the groupoid of vector bundles with connection over a fixed manifold MMM.

So, given a vector bundle E→ME \to ME→M with connection, the vector bundle End(E)→M\mathsf{End}(E) \to MEnd(E)→M gets a connection.

This implies that given an endofunctor on core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect)- of which the dual space and endomorphism space functors are- there's somehow also then an endofunctor on core(VectWithConnection)\mathsf{core(VectWithConnection)}core(VectWithConnection) that sends a vector bundle equipped with a connection to the dual bundle/endomorphism bundle equipped with the "correct" connection. But as I pointed out above, a functor on the category of vector bundles won't uniquely extend to a functor on the category of bundles with connection, since this is extra structure that can be specified multiple times for the same object. So how would this problem be resolved?

James Deikun (Oct 23 2024 at 12:40):

John Baez said:

The point of all this baloney, lest we lose sight of it, is that parallel transport along a path always gives an isomorphism from one fiber to another. So, we expect any construction we can do to fibers, which is functorial with respect to isomorphisms, can serve as a way to build a new bundle from an old one, and also turn a connection on the old one into a connection on the new one.

:point_up:

To be more precise: you can see a connection as a smooth functor from points and smooth paths into core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect), giving for each point the fiber and for each path the holonomy, and you can postcompose by your other functor to get a new connection on your new bundle. It's not that every functor on the category of vector bundles extends to a functor on the category of bundles with connection, it's that the way you're deriving these functors from functors on core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect) automatically also gives you a blessed extension.

John Baez (Oct 23 2024 at 16:20):

John Onstead said:

That's very interesting! It seems that ddd acts as a sort of partial derivative, and so requires local coordinates to make sense, which can only be specified after the trivialization. At least I hope I'm understanding that right!

I don't think we need coordinates, though I get what you mean, and in my exposition I used coordinates because it was easy.

If I were trying to work coordinate-free, I'd say that ddd is a concept that makes sense for map f:M→Nf: M \to Nf:M→N, but to treat a section of a vector bundle over E→ME \to ME→M as a map f:M→Vf: M \to Vf:M→V for some vector space VVV, we need to choose a trivialization E≅M×VE \cong M \times VE≅M×V, identifying each fiber with VVV.

Then from a section s:M→E≅M×Vs: M \to E \cong M \times Vs:M→E≅M×V we can extract a function f:M→Vf: M \to Vf:M→V, and we can take ddd of that getting df:TM→TVdf: TM \to TVdf:TM→TV, but then we can use the canonical isomorphisms TV≅V×VTV \cong V \times VTV≅V×V to extract from this a map TM→VTM \to VTM→V which is a VVV-valued 1-form. We may then sloppily call that VVV-valued 1-form "dsdsds".

In my exposition I chose V=RnV = \mathbb{R}^nV=Rn and used coordinates just to make the explanation a lot quicker!

John Baez (Oct 23 2024 at 16:36):

TL;DR: we can take ddd of a section of a trivialized vector bundle and get a vector-valued 1-form. But the answer depends on the trivialization.

Another way to put this is that every trivialized vector bundle E→ME \to ME→M has a god-given flat connection called ddd.

A difference of connections is an End(E)\mathrm{End}(E)End(E)-valued 1-form. Thus, given any other connection DDD on our trivialized vector bundle EEE, the difference

D−d=A D - d = AD−d=A

is an End(E)\mathrm{End}(E)End(E)-valued 1-form, and we can write

D=d+A D = d + AD=d+A.

But ddd and thus AAA depend on the choice of trivialization. And of course most vector bundles don't have any trivialization.

John Baez (Oct 23 2024 at 16:53):

John Onstead said:

John Baez said:

Next, any endofunctor F:core(Vect)→core(Vect)F : \mathsf{core(Vect)} \to \mathsf{core(Vect)} F:core(Vect)→core(Vect) acts on the groupoid of vector bundles with connection over a fixed manifold MMM.

So, given a vector bundle E→ME \to ME→M with connection, the vector bundle End(E)→M\mathsf{End}(E) \to MEnd(E)→M gets a connection.

This implies that given an endofunctor on core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect)- of which the dual space and endomorphism space functors are- there's somehow also then an endofunctor on core(VectWithConnection)\mathsf{core(VectWithConnection)}core(VectWithConnection) that sends a vector bundle equipped with a connection to the dual bundle/endomorphism bundle equipped with the "correct" connection. But as I pointed out above, a functor on the category of vector bundles won't uniquely extend to a functor on the category of bundles with connection, since this is extra structure that can be specified multiple times for the same object. So how would this problem be resolved?

We don't try to do such an extension; as you point out, it's too nonunique.

We should probably start by talking about the important functor

E:[core(Vect),core(Vect)]→[core(VectM),core(VectM)] E: [\mathsf{core(Vect)}, \mathsf{core(Vect)}] \to [\mathsf{core(Vect}_M), \mathsf{core(Vect}_M)] E:[core(Vect),core(Vect)]→[core(VectM​),core(VectM​)]

Here Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect is my sloppy notation for the category of finite-dimensional vector spaces, and VectM\mathsf{Vect}_MVectM​ is the category of (finite-dimensional) vector bundles over a fixed manifold MMM.

Here's the idea behind this functor EEE. Any decent procedure for getting new (finite-dimensional) vector spaces from old ones gives a procedure for getting new vector bundles from old ones. Just apply the procedure to each fiber!

After we understand EEE, we can move on to the important functor

F:[core(Vect),core(Vect)]→[core(VectConnM),core(VectConnM)] F: [\mathsf{core(Vect)}, \mathsf{core(Vect)}] \to [\mathsf{core(VectConn}_M), \mathsf{core(VectConn}_M)] F:[core(Vect),core(Vect)]→[core(VectConnM​),core(VectConnM​)]

Here VectConnM\mathsf{VectConn}_MVectConnM​ is the category of vector bundles with connection over a fixed manifold MMM.

Any decent procedure for getting new (finite-dimensional) vector spaces from old ones gives a procedure for getting new vector bundles with connection from old ones!

Btw, congrats on the LaTeX! The easiest way to learn LaTeX is to copy little bits of other people's LaTeX and pay attention to how it works.

John Onstead (Oct 23 2024 at 18:44):

James Deikun said:

To be more precise: you can see a connection as a smooth functor from points and smooth paths into core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect), giving for each point the fiber and for each path the holonomy, and you can postcompose by your other functor to get a new connection on your new bundle. It's not that every functor on the category of vector bundles extends to a functor on the category of bundles with connection, it's that the way you're deriving these functors from functors on core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect) automatically also gives you a blessed extension.

Thanks, that makes sense!
Earlier, I was given the definition for a principal connection in this way, so I'd been wondering how to define a vector bundle connection functorially- this helps clear that up too!

John Onstead (Oct 23 2024 at 18:50):

John Baez said:

If I were trying to work coordinate-free, I'd say that ddd is a concept that makes sense for map f:M→Nf: M \to Nf:M→N, but to treat a section of a vector bundle over E→ME \to ME→M as a map f:M→Vf: M \to Vf:M→V for some vector space VVV, we need to choose a trivialization E≅M×VE \cong M \times VE≅M×V, identifying each fiber with VVV.

Then from a section s:M→E≅M×Vs: M \to E \cong M \times Vs:M→E≅M×V we can extract a function f:M→Vf: M \to Vf:M→V, and we can take ddd of that getting df:TM→TVdf: TM \to TVdf:TM→TV, but then we can use the canonical isomorphisms TV≅V×VTV \cong V \times VTV≅V×V to extract from this a map TM→VTM \to VTM→V which is a VVV-valued 1-form. We may then sloppily call that VVV-valued 1-form "dsdsds".

From this it seems you are implying that ddd is just the differential we were talking about earlier, where for a function f:M→Nf: M \to Nf:M→N, df:TM→TNdf: TM \to TNdf:TM→TN. But if this is the case, then why can't you just define ddd for a section of a vector bundle given by s:M→Es: M \to Es:M→E to be the differential ds:TM→TEds: TM \to TEds:TM→TE? In other words, why go through all the business of converting the section back into a map into VVV before taking the differential when you could just directly take the differential instead?
Edit: Thought about this for a bit longer- maybe you can take the differential ddd as I described, but it won't be a 1-form, and we need it to be?

Also, the above seems to strongly imply that ddd, and thus the formula D=d+AD = d + AD=d+A, only works for a trivial bundle, and doesn't work for the more general locally trivial bundle. If so, then how do things work in the latter situation? To me the formula D=d+AD = d + AD=d+A "means" that the covariant derivative is the usual derivative plus a "correction factor", given by the connection 1-form A, that takes into account the curvature of the space. Is this interpretation of a covariant derivative not always possible then?

James Deikun (Oct 23 2024 at 19:33):

It's always possible locally, but sometimes the "usual" derivative isn't globally definable, and the "correction" gets the job of bridging between the different local derivatives.

John Baez (Oct 23 2024 at 22:32):

James Deikun said:

To be more precise: you can see a connection as a smooth functor from points and smooth paths into core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect), giving for each point the fiber and for each path the holonomy, and you can postcompose by your other functor to get a new connection on your new bundle. It's not that every functor on the category of vector bundles extends to a functor on the category of bundles with connection, it's that the way you're deriving these functors from functors on core(Vect)\mathsf{core(Vect)}core(Vect) automatically also gives you a blessed extension.

Thanks for explaining the idea. We've got this groupoid of paths in MMM, say P(M)P(M)P(M), and a vector-bundle-with-connection is a functor

hol:P(M)→Vect \mathrm{hol} : P(M) \to \mathsf{Vect} hol:P(M)→Vect

obeying a certain smoothness condition. Since P(M)P(M)P(M) is a groupoid, this is the same as a smooth functor

hol:P(M)→core(Vect) \mathrm{hol} : P(M) \to \mathsf{core(Vect)} hol:P(M)→core(Vect)

Then, given any smooth functor

K:core(Vect)→core(Vect) K: \mathsf{core(Vect)} \to \mathsf{core(Vect)} K:core(Vect)→core(Vect)

we can form

K∘hol:P(M)→core(Vect)K \circ \mathrm{hol} : P(M) \to \mathsf{core(Vect)} K∘hol:P(M)→core(Vect)

which is a new vector-bundle-with-connection.

So, any smooth functor K:core(Vect)→core(Vect) K: \mathsf{core(Vect)} \to \mathsf{core(Vect)} K:core(Vect)→core(Vect) gives a functorial way to get new vector-bundles-with-connection from old ones!

If we want to get really serious we should talk about the smoothness conditions someday. Then we can also do this example:

We can think of MMM as giving a smooth groupoid with MMM as its space of objects and only identity morphisms, say disc(M)\mathsf{disc}(M)disc(M). A vector bundle on MMM should be the same as a smooth functor

E:disc(M)→core(Vect) E : \mathsf{disc}(M) \to \mathsf{core(Vect)}E:disc(M)→core(Vect)

Thus, we can compose with KKK to get a new vector bundle

K∘E:disc(M)→core(Vect) K \circ E: \mathsf{disc}(M) \to \mathsf{core(Vect)}K∘E:disc(M)→core(Vect)

So, any smooth functor K:core(Vect)→core(Vect) K: \mathsf{core(Vect)} \to \mathsf{core(Vect)} K:core(Vect)→core(Vect) gives a functorial way to get new vector bundles from old ones!

John Onstead (Oct 24 2024 at 11:28):

Thanks James Deikun and John Baez for your help! I'm still updating my notes on all this, it's a lot to take in. But while I do that, I have a question that came to mind when we were discussing second derivatives above. Given DDD an exterior covariant derivative, we denote F=D2F=D^2F=D2 for a curvature form FFF. As we covered, the curvature is interpreted to precisely be the measure of how much failure there is for the exterior covariant derivative to square to zero as a "normal" exterior derivative would. But this reminds me a lot of something I learned in first year calculus class- that the second derivative is a measure of the "curvature" of a function. By any chance, are these two concepts related in any way? Or is it just a weird coincidence that the second covariant exterior derivative and the second usual derivative both yield some notion of "curvature"?

John Baez (Oct 24 2024 at 16:41):

It's the same business: first derivatives describe the linear - i.e., flat - approximation to something like a function, or section of a bundle, or submanifold of a manifold, or Riemannian manifold, while second derivatives describe the 'deviation from flatness': the failure of the linear approximation to be exactly correct. Curvature is the failure of something to be exactly flat.

John Baez (Oct 24 2024 at 16:42):

There are also third derivatives, which measure even subtler kinds of bending, and so on.

John Baez (Oct 24 2024 at 16:48):

A good way to bring this stuff down to earth is to look at a 2-dimensional manifold with a Riemannian metric. If its Riemann curvature tensor is zero, it's flat: it looks locally exactly like a plane. If its curvature tensor is nonzero, we get a better local approximation to its shape using an ellipsoid ('positive curvature') or hyperboloid ('negative curvature').

John Baez (Oct 24 2024 at 16:49):

In general relativity, the 'principle equivalence' says that to first order we can always locally approximate spacetime by Minkowski spacetime - so very small and short-lived experiments in free fall behave almost like they do in Minkowski spacetime, which is flat. But when we go to second order, we see effects of curvature - i.e., gravity.

John Baez (Oct 24 2024 at 16:51):

You could say it's all about Taylor series. Physicists like to joke that "to first order, everything is linear". You can go quite far linearizing everything. But then there should be another saying: "to second order, everything is quadratic". That's where curvature shows up.

John Onstead (Oct 30 2024 at 11:42):

Hi! My apologies for dropping off, things have been getting busier.

In preparation for better understanding Lagrangians, I've been reviewing the calculus of variation and what it "looks like" in this fiber bundle/manifold perspective. Calculus of variations centers around "functional derivatives", which are derivatives of functionals. First, I want to make sure I understand what a functional "looks like" in the category of smooth manifolds- is it sufficient to say it is simply a smooth map of the following form F:C∞(M)→RF: C^{\infty}(M) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}F:C∞(M)→R? This would take in a real valued function defined on the manifold MMM and return a real number- this is basically a functional, right? If so, then is a functional derivative simply the differential of this map: dF:TC∞(M)→TRdF: TC^{\infty}(M) \rightarrow T\mathbb{R}dF:TC∞(M)→TR?

However, I've also seen the notion of a "functional derivative" formalized in terms of Gateaux Derivatives, which according to Wikipedia generalize directional derivatives. But I thought differentials generalized directional derivatives? Maybe I'm not understanding something correctly!

John Baez (Oct 30 2024 at 23:36):

"Functional derivatives" have been formalized in many ways - Gateaux derivatives, Frechet derivatives, and others. But until you need to learn about these, it's probably easier to work in your favorite cartesian closed category of smooth spaces (e.g. diffeological spaces), and say something like what you said:

In physics a "field" is often described as a smooth section of a fiber bundle EEE over a smooth space BBB. The space of all smooth sections is a smooth space in itself, say Γ(E)\Gamma(E)Γ(E). Given any function F:Γ(E)→RF: \Gamma(E) \to \mathbb{R}F:Γ(E)→R we can define its functional derivative to be its differential dF:TΓ(E)→TRdF: T\Gamma(E) \to T\mathbb{R}dF:TΓ(E)→TR, which in turn gives a 1-form on Γ(E)\Gamma(E)Γ(E) also often called dFdFdF.

John Baez (Oct 30 2024 at 23:38):

(I said a field is often described as a smooth section of a fiber bundle, because we've already seen a case where it's not: a connection is not a smooth section of a fiber bundle until we fix a 'reference connection' and describe other connections in terms of that one.)

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 01:35):

Thanks, that makes sense! And I guess generalizing derivatives to differentials or to Frechet/Gateaux derivatives are just different directions of generalization. They both start in Euclidean space, but one generalizes to manifolds and differential geometry while the other generalizes to topological vector spaces and formal analysis.

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 01:46):

I've been learning so much about gauge theory and fiber bundles for the past few weeks and it's been really informative! I've certainly appreciated all the help along the way. But I think most of the mathematical basis has been covered (either by this discussion or the book), so this might be a natural pausing place for this topic. That's not to say there isn't still a lot to go through- mainly specific applications to physics, but I'll come back to those at a later point in time. Let me know if there's anything you think is important to remember about the mathematics of gauge theory that we might not have gone over yet!

As for what to do next, I wanted to talk more about the motivations of sheaves, inspired by the recent discussion of sites and their motivation. I'd only passively been interested in sheaves, but my interest in learning about them, and how they relate to locality, has been excited by our previous discussion on germs and how they relate to jets. So far, I've seen sheaves be motivated as providing help in "local-global problems", but I want to make this notion more concrete by identifying the exact class of local-global problems that sheaves have use in, and clearly distinguish this class from the class of local-global problems where sheaves cannot help (I'm talking very generally here, so even applying outside the domain of topology). Hopefully I will be able to do this at some point within this next discussion! I'll probably start a new topic for that when I have gotten my questions in order.

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 02:32):

As usual I want to keep going deeper: talking about the concepts of bundle, connection and curvature without talking about Yang-Mills theory or general relativity is like eating an appetizer and then leaving the restaurant before dinner is served! But that's okay: if you feel you've had enough that's fine.

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 04:19):

John Baez said:

As usual I want to keep going deeper: talking about the concepts of bundle, connection and curvature without talking about Yang-Mills theory or general relativity is like eating an appetizer and then leaving the restaurant before dinner is served! But that's okay: if you feel you've had enough that's fine.

Don't worry! I'm excited to learn more about these concepts, I'm just taking a quick break for the time being to get to some other topics I was curious about. But I will certainly circle back!

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 05:19):

Okay. I will try to hang back and let other people do most of the talking about sheaves, since a lot of people here understand sheaves better than me, particularly sheaves on general sites and their topos-theoretic aspects. I'm mainly a student of sheaves, especially their applications to complex geometry and algebraic geometry a la Griffiths and Harris' Principles of Algebraic Geometry.

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 11:14):

Actually, before I go on to sheaves, I was reviewing my notes and discovered another question I wanted to ask. Above, we saw how composing a vector-bundle-with-connection-as-a-functor C:P(M)→core(Vect) C : \mathsf{P}(M) \to \mathsf{core(Vect)}C:P(M)→core(Vect) with some F:core(Vect)→core(Vect) F : \mathsf{core(Vect)} \to \mathsf{core(Vect)}F:core(Vect)→core(Vect) allows one to "transfer" connections functorially. This reminded me of a discussion we had a while ago about transferring connections- not between a bundle and its dual or endomorphism bundle, but instead between a principal bundle and an associated bundle. This made me wonder if there's an analogous way to view that transfer as a composition of functors, exactly like what we did above.

Take a principal G-bundle with connection given by C:P(M)→core(G-Tor) C : \mathsf{P}(M) \to \mathsf{core}(G{\text -}\mathsf{Tor})C:P(M)→core(G-Tor). The above would require there to be, for every representation RRR, a functor R:core(G-Tor)→core(Vect) R : \mathsf{core}(G{\text -}\mathsf{Tor}) \to \mathsf{core(Vect)}R:core(G-Tor)→core(Vect) such that the composition of CCC and RRR would precisely yield the associated vector bundle already equipped with the appropriate connection. However, I can't seem to define this functor RRR. As mentioned in Urs' article, there's certainly a functor R′:BG→core(Vect) R' : BG \to \mathsf{core(Vect)}R′:BG→core(Vect) since a representation of a group is just a functor from the one object category into vector spaces. So while we can compose a functor C′:P(M)→BG C' : \mathsf{P}(M) \to BGC′:P(M)→BG with R′R'R′, the functor C′C'C′ is the definition of a principal bundle with connection assuming a trivialization, as we discussed above. My question is then: is there any way to define the transfer of a connection in a functorial way, as I am trying to do above, without reference to a trivialization, or is that just completely impossible to do? That is, does the functor RRR as I defined it above exist, is well-defined, and is easily constructible?

(Also, Happy Halloween!)

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 15:25):

:pumpkin: Happy Halloween, @John Onstead! :pumpkin:

And thanks for a very engaging conversation.

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 15:28):

This is a great question. Let's see if I can figure out an answer. I'll just concentrate on how we associate a vector bundle to a principal bundle, somehow turning each fiber of the principal GGG-bundle into a vector space using a representation of GGG.

Say I have a representation of the Lie group GGG, i.e. a Lie group homomorphism

ρ:G→Aut(V)\rho: G \to \mathrm{Aut}(V)ρ:G→Aut(V)

where VVV is a finite-dimensional vector space and Aut(V)\mathrm{Aut}(V)Aut(V) is its Lie group of automorphisms, usually called the [[general linear group]] GL(V)\mathrm{GL}(V)GL(V).

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 15:33):

Let TTT be a GGG-torsor. Then we can "associate" to it a vector that people often call T×GV T \times_G VT×G​V. I'll describe its underlying set: it's the quotient of T×GT \times GT×G by the equivalence relation

(tg,v)∼(t,ρ(g)v) (t g, v) \sim (t , \rho(g) v) (tg,v)∼(t,ρ(g)v)

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 15:34):

In other words, we have a coequalizer diagram in Set\mathsf{Set}Set:

G→→T×G→T×GV G \stackrel{\to}{\to} T \times G \to T \times_G V G→→T×G→T×G​V

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 15:39):

But in fact T×GVT \times_G VT×G​V has the structure of a vector space! That's because elements of T×GVT \times_G VT×G​V are equivalence classes [t,v][t,v][t,v], but because TTT is a torsor every such equivalence class is equal to a unique one of the form [1,u][1,u][1,u], and we can define vector space operations by

[1,u]+[1,u′]=[1,u+u′] [1,u] + [1,u'] = [1,u+u'][1,u]+[1,u′]=[1,u+u′]
c[1,u]=[c,u] c[1,u] = [c, u] c[1,u]=[c,u]

where u,u′∈Vu,u' \in Vu,u′∈V and c∈Rc \in \mathbb{R}c∈R or C\mathbb{C}C.

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 15:41):

So, your desired functor

core(G−Tor)→core(Vect)\mathsf{core}(G\mathsf{-Tor}) \to \mathsf{core}(\mathsf{Vect})core(G−Tor)→core(Vect)

sends any GGG-torsor TTT to the vector space T×GVT \times_G VT×G​V.

Of course I should really check that the vector space structure on T×GVT \times_G VT×G​V is well-defined, and define your desired functor on morphisms, and check that it's really a functor! But I'm a lazy guy so won't.

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 18:19):

By the way, I didn't solve this problem in the most elegant and general way. It actually has very little to do with vector spaces!

I think the real key is that

G−Tor≃BG G\mathsf{-Tor} \simeq \mathsf{B}GG−Tor≃BG

In other words, the category of GGG-torsors is equivalent to the one-object category with elements of GGG as morphisms anf multiplication as composition!

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 18:21):

This makes it easy to turn a representation of GGG on a vector space into a functor from GGG-torsors into vector spaces!

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 18:22):

But this slick approach matches the clunkier 'standard' approach I described before.

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 20:09):

John Baez said:

So, your desired functor

core(G−Tor)→core(Vect)\mathsf{core}(G\mathsf{-Tor}) \to \mathsf{core}(\mathsf{Vect})core(G−Tor)→core(Vect)

sends any GGG-torsor TTT to the vector space T×GVT \times_G VT×G​V.

Of course I should really check that the vector space structure on T×GVT \times_G VT×G​V is well-defined, and define your desired functor on morphisms, and check that it's really a functor! But I'm a lazy guy so won't.

Oh thanks I think that solves my problem! I'm pretty sure this functor is well defined since I think it's actually doing the opposite of what we noticed above. There, we realized an endofunctor in core(Vect)\mathsf{core}(\mathsf{Vect})core(Vect) could "lift" to an endofunctor on core(VectBund)\mathsf{core}(\mathsf{VectBund})core(VectBund) (with the same being true for endofunctors on the core of G-Tor "lifting" to those on the core of the category of G-principal bundles). In this case, we can go the opposite direction: we can start with the usual associated bundle functor between the category of G-principal bundles and vector bundles given some representation, restrict this to a functor between the cores of both respective categories, and then show that this functor "lowers" to one between the core of G-Tor and Vect. It would suffice to show that the functor on the bundles acts fiberwise, which I'm confident it does (maybe it can be seen as "swapping out" fibers in some way?)

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 20:11):

Yes, the point of the associated bundle construction is that it swaps out each fiber in our principal bundle, which is a GGG-torsor TTT, with some other fiber T×GFT \times_G FT×G​F, where FFF, called the standard fiber, is some chosen thing on which GGG acts.

We always have T×GF≅FT \times_G F \cong FT×G​F≅F, but this isomorphism is not canonical. If it were, the associated bundle would always be trivial!

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 20:13):

John Baez said:

I think the real key is that

G−Tor≃BG G\mathsf{-Tor} \simeq \mathsf{B}GG−Tor≃BG

In other words, the category of GGG-torsors is equivalent to the one-object category with elements of GGG as morphisms and multiplication as composition!

I noticed this too- since the core of G-Tor is a connected groupoid it would "collapse" to a single object under the skeleton construction. But the problem here is that while the categories are equivalent, I don't think there is a canonical equivalence- it's basically the higher up version of how there's no canonical isomorphism for torsors! It seems that each choice of equivalence G−Tor≃BG G\mathsf{-Tor} \simeq \mathsf{B}GG−Tor≃BG thus corresponds to a choice of trivialization. But I could be completely wrong about all this!

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 20:17):

Actually there's a god-given functor BG→G−Tor\mathsf{B}G \to G-\mathsf{Tor}BG→G−Tor which does this:

  • it sends the one object ⋆∈BG\star \in \mathsf{B}G⋆∈BG to the GGG-torsor GGG (with its usual right action on itself)
  • it sends any morphism g:⋆→⋆g: \star \to \starg:⋆→⋆ (which is just an element of GGG) to the GGG-torsor morphism Lg:G→GL_g: G \to GLg​:G→G (that is, left multiplication by g∈Gg \in Gg∈G).

And this is an equivalence of categories!

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 20:20):

So we should really think of G−TorG\mathsf{-Tor}G−Tor as just another way of thinking about BG\mathsf{B}GBG. I should probably have said this about two months ago. It's a way of thinking about BG\mathsf{B}GBG where the faceless single object ⋆∈BG\star \in \mathsf{B} G⋆∈BG is replaced by a bunch of objects that have a bit more personality. Torsors feel more like "interesting mathematical structures" than a boring old ⋆\star⋆, a random symbol I've drawn on the page. But they're all isomorphic so in some sense this is a sham. What's really interesting is the morphisms between them!

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 20:22):

This shift of viewpoint, while trivial in a way, is actually quite profound in how it makes us think about things differently. I don't think geometers could get interested in principal bundles if they didn't think of torsors as "interesting mathematical structures" - namely, nonempty spaces with a free and transitive action of GGG.

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 21:19):

John Baez said:

Actually there's a god-given functor BG→G−Tor\mathsf{B}G \to G-\mathsf{Tor}BG→G−Tor which does this:

  • it sends the one object ⋆∈BG\star \in \mathsf{B}G⋆∈BG to the GGG-torsor GGG (with its usual right action on itself)
  • it sends any morphism g:⋆→⋆g: \star \to \starg:⋆→⋆ (which is just an element of GGG) to the GGG-torsor morphism Lg:G→GL_g: G \to GLg​:G→G (that is, left multiplication by g∈Gg \in Gg∈G).

I'm still slightly confused. A functor BG→G−Tor\mathsf{B}G \to G-\mathsf{Tor}BG→G−Tor involves a mapping of homs Hom(⋆,⋆)→Hom(T,T)\mathsf{Hom}(\star, \star) \to \mathsf{Hom}(T, T)Hom(⋆,⋆)→Hom(T,T). But this is just a map G→Aut(T)G \to \mathsf{Aut}(T)G→Aut(T), but earlier we stated there isn't a canonical map from a group into the automorphism group of a torsor! Maybe I'm misremembering something, since that discussion was a while ago?

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 21:24):

John Baez said:

It turns out that if you have a principal bundle P→BP \to BP→B, each fiber PbP_bPb​ for b∈Bb \in Bb∈B is a torsor of GGG. The automorphism group of this torsor is isomorphic to GGG, but not canonically, and in many cases this prevents us from identifying gauge transformations with smooth functions g:B→Gg: B \to Gg:B→G. (Not only is there not a canonical identification, there's none at all.)

This is what I mean!

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 21:37):

John Onstead said:

I'm still slightly confused. A functor BG→G−Tor\mathsf{B}G \to G-\mathsf{Tor}BG→G−Tor involves a mapping of homs Hom(⋆,⋆)→Hom(T,T)\mathsf{Hom}(\star, \star) \to \mathsf{Hom}(T, T)Hom(⋆,⋆)→Hom(T,T). But this is just a map G→Aut(T)G \to \mathsf{Aut}(T)G→Aut(T), but earlier we stated there isn't a canonical map from a group into the automorphism group of a torsor!

That's true - but note in my functor BG→G−Tor\mathsf{B}G \to G-\mathsf{Tor}BG→G−Tor I am sending ⋆\star⋆ not to just any old random torsor, but to GGG itself, viewed as a right GGG-torsor! The automorphism group of this GGG-torsor is isomorphic to GGG in a standard way, since its automorphisms are just left translations by elements of GGG.

So this functor is god-given as can be. Maybe your point amounts to this: there's not a god given weak inverse to this functor! A weak inverse would need to send an automorphism of an arbitrary GGG-torsor to an element of GGG.

(By weak inverse I mean 'inverse up to natural isomorphism, so an equivalence is a functor FFF with a weak inverse Fˉ\bar{F}Fˉ, but there are several ways to think about this: we can demand the mere existence of the weak inverse, or a specified weak inverse Fˉ\bar{F}Fˉ, or a specified weak inverse Fˉ\bar{F}Fˉ together with a choice of natural isomorphisms FˉF→1,FFˉ→1\bar{F} F \to 1, F \bar{F} \to 1FˉF→1,FFˉ→1.)

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 21:43):

So, this is a subtle issue... and we should expect all these irritatingly subtle issues to bite us in the ass when we are trying to delve into the very essence of symmetry, which is all about how things can be 'the same'.

However while there are various ways to choose all the data of an equivalence

BG→G−Tor\mathsf{B}G \to G-\mathsf{Tor}BG→G−Tor

I am merely claiming that such an equivalence exists. If we pick one, we get a way to turn any action of GGG on any object in any category C\mathsf{C}C, meaning a functor

ρ:BG→C \rho: \mathsf{B}G \to \mathsf{C}ρ:BG→C

into a functor

G−Tor→C G-\mathsf{Tor} \to \mathsf{C}G−Tor→C

This lets do the "associated bundle" trick starting from a principal GGG-bundle and an action of GGG on anything in any category.

John Baez (Oct 31 2024 at 21:44):

We can now have the fun (or pain) of studying how this construction depends on our choice of equivalence BG→G−Tor\mathsf{B}G \to G-\mathsf{Tor}BG→G−Tor.

John Onstead (Oct 31 2024 at 22:21):

Ah I see, thanks for the explanation!

John Onstead (Nov 01 2024 at 11:34):

I know I said I'd take a break from bundles but then another question popped into my head, and I think this one might be a good example for contextualizing all of what we've covered so far. Given a symmetry of nature, Noether's theorem states there exists a corresponding conserved quantity. Secondly, the conservation law can be given as a "continuity equation", either in integral or differential form (via the divergence theorem, these two are equivalent). In differential form, it's written as dJ=0dJ = 0dJ=0 where JJJ is the conserved current.

So here's my question. Let's say you are handed a random group GGG, corresponding to some "symmetry of nature". You can of course construct the principal GGG-bundle for this group PPP on something like Minkowski space. But Noether's theorem seems to guarantee that, somehow, just by being given this group and bundle, at some point down the road you will arrive at some equation of the form dJ=0dJ = 0dJ=0- not only that, but you will arrive here in a non-arbitrary way. My question is: how? What is the step by step procedure of realizing Noether's theorem/getting from PPP to dJ=0dJ = 0dJ=0 from the fiber bundle perspective, making use of things we've covered like associated bundles, connections, etc. as needed? (though of course the specific connection and representation shouldn't matter since Noether's theorem needs to apply in all cases) I know Noether's theorem makes the most sense in the context of Lagrangian mechanics, but my goal here is to get a general sense of how it works in the context of fiber bundles alone without reference- or at least as little reference as possible- to Lagrangians or Lagrangian mechanics.

James Deikun (Nov 01 2024 at 12:03):

You're probably not totally going to get that since Noether's theorem is something that's true at the level of mechanics, not dynamical systems in general.

John Baez (Nov 01 2024 at 21:48):

John Onstead said:

So here's my question. Let's say you are handed a random group GGG, corresponding to some "symmetry of nature". You can of course construct the principal GGG-bundle for this group PPP on something like Minkowski space. But Noether's theorem seems to guarantee that, somehow, just by being given this group and bundle, at some point down the road you will arrive at some equation of the form dJ=0dJ = 0dJ=0 - not only that, but you will arrive here in a non-arbitrary way.

No, you won't get a 1-form JJJ with dJ=0d J = 0dJ=0 starting from so little information. Noether's theorem says that if you have some fields on spacetime, and a Lagrangian that depends on these fields, and GGG acts on these fields in such a way that the Lagrangian is invariant up to a total divergence, then you get a 1-form JJJ, and this obeys dJ=0d J = 0dJ=0 when the field equations coming from the Lagrangian hold. But JJJ depends on the Lagrangian, and you need to use the field equations to show dJ=0d J = 0dJ=0.

It's probably good to look at the statement and easy proof of Noether's theorem. Here is a version for fields of the form ϕ:M→T\phi: M \to Tϕ:M→T where MMM and TTT are any manifolds. There are more general versions but the argument is always similar.

John Onstead (Nov 01 2024 at 22:27):

Ok, so Noether's theorem does require the Lagrangian after all. I think I was confusing a few things. First, I mistakenly thought you could derive a law dJ=0dJ = 0dJ=0 for any representation and connection since you can derive a curvature FFF and Bianchi identity DF=0DF = 0DF=0 for any representation and connection, and I know that Maxwell's equations (which include a continuity equation for charge) can be derived from the Bianchi identity. But I'm guessing I got this wrong probably because the Bianchi identity isn't the only component of Maxwell's equations, you also need the Yang-Mills term. I'll certainly go back and review that again!

I also think I confused two notions of "charge". There's "charge as a representation" where you can index certain representations of a U(1)U(1)U(1) bundle by a number known as the "charge" which you've mentioned above. But then there's "charge as a physical property" which can have a density across space and be a field in itself. I conflated these two when in reality they are two separate things! It seems that in the case of the former, in QFT, the choice of "charge" would dictate how much electric charge the particles of the QFT would possess (so, for the electron field, the charge representation would be 1, while for a quark it might be 2/3 or 1/3). Meanwhile, the latter is used for when you have a charge density across space, such as when you have a lot of electrons together moving around in space.

John Baez (Nov 01 2024 at 23:22):

John Onstead said:

Ok, so Noether's theorem does require the Lagrangian after all. I think I was confusing a few things. First, I mistakenly thought you could derive a law dJ=0dJ = 0dJ=0 for any representation and connection since you can derive a curvature FFF and Bianchi identity DF=0DF = 0DF=0 for any representation and connection...

The Bianchi identity dDF=0d_D F = 0dD​F=0 says that the exterior covariant derivative of some Ad(P)\mathrm{Ad}(P)Ad(P)-valued 2-form, the curvature FFF, must vanish. This is just a fact about connections and their curvature. But to state conservation of charge in the form dD⋆J=0d_D \star J = 0dD​⋆J=0 requires that you cook up a 1-form JJJ on nnn-dimensional spacetime. And this quantity, called the current, depends on fields other than the connection, in a manner that depends on the Lagrangian.

I know that Maxwell's equations (which include a continuity equation for charge) can be derived from the Bianchi identity.

No, they can't. If they could, Maxwell's equations would be a mathematical tautology rather than a law of physics that needs to be checked experimentally!

It's true that half of Maxwell's equations are a mathematical tautology when formulated in terms of AAA, and this half is the Bianchi identity:

dDF=0 d_D F = 0 dD​F=0

But it's the other half, the non-tautological Maxwell equations, that give the actual physics:

⋆dD⋆F=J \star d_D \star F = J ⋆dD​⋆F=J

including the continuity equation

dD⋆J=0 d_D \star J = 0dD​⋆J=0

Here I'm writing everything down in sufficient generality that it applies to Yang-Mills theory - see page 261 of my book. If you only want Maxwell equations, take Ad(P)\mathrm{Ad}(P)Ad(P) to be a trivial line bundle and dD=dd_D = ddD​=d.

Last updated: Feb 28 2026 at 12:12 UTC

This archive runs on a customization of zulip-archive
